P.title: Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolves Yes if one of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:
Donald Trump
Donald Trump Jr.
Eric Trump
Ivanka Trump
Tiffany Trump
Melania Trump
Barron Trump

Q_given_P: This conditional probability reflects the likelihood of climate change occurring given that a Trump family member is the nominee. It may be affected by the policies that a Trump nominee might advocate for regarding climate change.

P.title: Will the price of water on the NQH20 hit $2,500 (2021 USD) per acre-foot by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the price of water hits $2500, adjusted for inflation to 2021 USD, on the NQH20 by 2050-01-01, 00:00 UTC. This question resolves negatively if the price of water does not hit $2500 by that date, and it resolves ambiguously if the NQH20 or a similar exchange doesn't continuously track California water prices up until 2050

For the current set of questions regarding the potential Republican nominee from the Trump family and the likelihood of global warming reaching at least 2°C by 2100, I will analyze the interdependencies and relationships between the probabilities involved.

1. **P (Trump Family Nominee)**: This question revolves around the likelihood of any member of the Trump family securing the Republican nomination for the US Presidency in 2024. Given Donald Trump's significant political presence and the potential for his family members to be candidates, I would estimate a relatively high probability for this event. 

2. **not_P (No Trump Family Nominee)**: This is the direct negation of P. Given the estimation for P, not_P will have a complementary probability. If P is high, not_P will be low.

3. **para_P (Possibility of Trump Family Nominee)**: This question essentially asks if it's possible for a Trump family member to secure the nomination. Given that P is estimated to be high, the probability for para_P should match P, as the possibility is directly tied to the likelihood of P occurring.

4. **Q (Global Warming)**: This question examines the probability of at least 2°C of global warming by 2100. Given the current scientific consensus on climate change, I would estimate a moderate to high probability for this event.

5. **P_and_Q (Both Events Occurring)**: This question depends on both P and Q being true. The probability here should reflect the joint occurrence of both events, which may be lower than either individual probability due to potential independence.

6. **P_or_Q (Either Event Occurring)**: This question allows for the occurrence of either P or Q. The probability for this should be higher than either P or Q alone, as it encompasses both scenarios.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Global Warming with No Trump Nominee)**: This question examines the scenario where global warming occurs, but no Trump family member is the nominee. The probability would depend on the individual probabilities of Q and not_P.

8. **Q_given_P (Global Warming Given Trump Nominee)**: This conditional question examines the likelihood of global warming occurring if a Trump family member is the nominee. This probability may be influenced by the political climate and policies associated with Trump family members, potentially affecting the estimate.

Overall, the relationships between these questions indicate a complex interplay of political and environmental factors. The consistency rules will guide the probability estimates to ensure they align logically and mathematically.

para_P.title: Is it expected that the Forethought Foundation will employ over two full-time equivalent staff members by 2025?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
In this context, a full-time equivalent is considered to be someone working 35 hours per week, excluding volunteers. The question will be resolved as 'No' if the project is evidently abandoned. Otherwise, reports from the organization and best estimates from Metaculus moderators will be utilized.

P.title: If Joe Biden is elected president of the US in 2020, will the highest tax bracket be restored to its original 39.6% or higher before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Joe Biden is elected president for the 2021-2024 term, and the upper tax bracket for US single tax payers is increased to at least 39.6% by January 1, 2025. If Biden is elected but the upper tax bracket is not increased to at least 39.6%, this question will resolve as No.
If Biden is not elected President in 2020, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

para_P.title: Should Joe Biden win the 2020 US presidential election, will the top tax rate be raised to 39.6% or more by 2025?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Joe Biden wins the 2020 presidential election and the highest tax rate for single taxpayers in the US is increased to at least 39.6% by January 1, 2025. If Biden wins but the highest tax rate is not raised to at least 39.6%, this question will resolve as No.
If Biden does not win the 2020 presidential election, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

P.title: Will smoking and sex be less prevalent in the United States in 2050 than in 2021?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the share of adults who have smoked in the past week and the share of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology (see fine print) to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys would result in positive resolution, conflicting surveys will be considered irrelevant.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodology, if a survey in 2021 includes e-cigarettes and a survey from 2050 does not the surveys would not be considered to have similar methodology. However, different methodologies can still be acceptable if it can be logically deduced that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For example, if a survey in 2021 asked whether respondents had sex in the past year and 25% answered no, and a survey in 2050 asked if respondents had sex in the past five years and 40% answered no, it can be deduced that a larger share of adults in 2050 had not had sex in the past year than in 2021 because the five year period would include the past year.

para_P.title: Will the rates of smoking and sexual activity be lower in the United States in 2050 compared to 2021?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the percentage of adults who have smoked in the past week and the percentage of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology (see fine print) to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys would result in positive resolution, conflicting surveys will be considered irrelevant.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodology, if a survey in 2021 includes e-cigarettes and a survey from 2050 does not, the surveys would not be considered to have similar methodology. However, different methodologies can still be acceptable if it can be logically deduced that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For example, if a survey in 2021 asked whether respondents had sex in the past year and 25% answered no, and a survey in 2050 asked if respondents had sex in the past five years and 40% answered no, it can be deduced that a larger share of adults in 2050 had not had sex in the past year than in 2021 because the five year period would include the past year.
